prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking up and kicking my girlfriend out of my apartment because she couldn’t pay rent?
She’s in the mindset that the guy should pay for everything, and against my better judgment I went with it. Any dinner, event, trip, hell even groceries I would help out with. She would pay for something once in awhile, and she would clean my apartment from time to time but I never felt like it was equal. Not that I have anything against paying for things, I believe the guy should pay for most, but there has to be some give and take

Fast forward to June 2018. She moves in my apartment in the city. For six months she’s living rent, bill, and virtually grocery free. Again she cleans but it’s not even. 

Fast forward again to now. We move in together so obviously we’re going to split the rent right? For a couple of months we did. Then the last week of February she tells me she won’t be able to pay anything for the rent due to her own debts and bills. I’m furious and she goes and stays with a friend for a week. I pay the full rent which puts me in a precarious financial situation for my own bills and debts. I was worried I wouldn’t be able to pay some of my own things (I was able to with money left over.) then this month comes. She originally says she could pay a few hundred because again, her own debts and bills. I’m wary but I say ok but you’ll have to pay me back. No real response. We talk again the other night and now she says she can’t pay anything at all again. I say ok so are you going to take care of the rent for a couple of months or pay me back? No because why do I have a boyfriend then?

This was the final straw. I’m supposed to help you out with your financial fires while mine get larger and you’re not even going to help me out when you can? Get the fuck out of my apartment. So once again, and for the rest of this lease, I’m paying the full rent. Paying half of it I would be in good shape. Could pay off bigger amounts in my cards and loans, but now I really have to penny pinch until business gets up again which could be a few months. 

We talked a couple days after this and she said it was a test to see how I would react in a tough situation. Like if she got into an accident or something. I believe this is a very very different situation but maybe I’m wrong and I overreacted 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves a breakup because the girlfriend couldn't pay rent.

First, I need to understand the key points. The author mentions that he believed the guy should pay for most things but expects some give and take. When they moved in together, they split rent initially, but she stopped contributing due to her debts. He ended up paying all the rent, leading to financial strain. He decided to kick her out because she wasn't contributing, and she later said it was a test. Now he's wondering if he was wrong.

So, the question is whether he overreacted or not. The options are A (yes, he's wrong) or B (no, he's not). To decide, I need to consider social norms around financial responsibilities in relationships, fairness, and communication.

In many relationships, splitting expenses is a common practice unless otherwise agreed. The author might have thought that he should take on most costs, but when it comes to living together, splitting rent is standard. The girlfriend's refusal to contribute could be seen as a lack of consideration for her partner's financial situation. The author's frustration seems justified given the financial strain. However, the way he handled it—kicking her out—might be seen as harsh, especially if there was prior agreement or if communication was lacking. 

Also, her claiming it was a test complicates things. If she intentionally created a stressful situation to see his reaction, maybe the author's response was appropriate. On the other hand, if he didn't communicate his expectations clearly from the start, that could be his fault. But the narrative suggests that she didn't contribute even after being asked, leading to him making a firm decision. 

Financial responsibility in relationships is important for both parties. If one person is consistently not pulling their weight, it's reasonable to reevaluate the relationship. The author's financial difficulties might make his actions understandable. However, some might argue that breaking up over financial issues could be seen as the man being too controlling or not compromising enough. 

Considering all these factors, the author's actions might not be in the wrong because he was protecting his financial stability. So the answer would be B (No).
